subNodes.conversationText: root

The young witch approached a camp. Several silken tents stood within, and <he/she> could smell cooking food and hear the music of bards. A few people inside saw <him/her> and were watching <him/her> curiously. A tall, stern-looking woman, spear in hand, accosted <him/her>.
[Continue.]

"You approach the royal escort of His Majesty, King Setus II of Dudow. Do you have business here?"

The guard seemed skeptical. The wear and tear of <FirstName>'s adventures gave <him/her> a wild look that didn't suggest royal business. At least Knott had become a normal gourd once again.

Pharaoh watched from an overhanging branch.
"The king? He's here?"
"He is. Again, do you have business in the camp?"
"Yes, I do," said the young witch.
"No business at all."
"Yes, I do," said the young witch.
"What is it?"
"I'm looking for a murderer."
"Well, there are no murderers here."
"Aren't all monarchs murderers?"
The woman glowered. "That sounds treasonous. Move along, stranger."
"Very well."
"Wait, wait," said a voice.
"I'll stay right here. I'm a witch, and you can't tell me what to do."
"Maybe. Still, someone here might have seen or heard something that could help me."
"I doubt it."
"Let me make sure, and then I'll be on my way."

"No. The royal encampment of a king is not a common room in which to ask questions. If your investigation is legitimate, I can assure you that you'll find no answers here. We haven't heard of or seen any murders in our travels. If it isn't, you're attempting to trespass. Either way, I'm warning you -- Leave."
"Very well."
"I'll stay right here. I'm a witch, and you can't tell me what to do."
"Can I not just pay my respects to the king?"

"A royal audience is an honor. It might take a foreign ambassador months to secure one. It might take an official with state business a year. Why on earth would my master, the Minister of Peace, grant this honor to a chance wayfarer?"
"I'm a witch. Let me through."

The woman took a step back.

"A witch? Are you -- Eldest Lady?"
"Do I look like I'd be named Eldest Lady?"
"Then you must be part of her coven!" This wasn't quite accurate, but <FirstName> didn't correct her.
[Continue.]
A short, slim man in fine clothes approached the two.
[Continue.]
"Minister?"
"No, but I know her."
"Then you must be part of her coven!" This wasn't quite accurate, but <FirstName> didn't correct her.
<FirstName> pursed <his/her> lips and said nothing.
The guard's eyes widened.
[Continue.]
A short, slim man in fine clothes approached the two.
"I'm a witch. I'll be the judge of that."

The woman took a step back.

"A witch? Are you -- Eldest Lady?"
"I wish to pay my respects to the king."

"A royal audience is an honor. It might take a foreign ambassador months to secure one. It might take an official with state business a year. Why on earth would my master, the Minister of Peace, grant this honor to a chance wayfarer?"
"That's a good question. I don't know."
"Be on your way then."
"Very well."
"I'll stay right here. I'm a witch, and you can't tell me what to do."

The woman took a step back.

"A witch? Are you -- Eldest Lady?"
"Because the chance wayfarer is better company than those people."
"You haven't met many lords or state officials, or you'd know that being good company has nothing to do with it. Be on your way."
"Very well."
"I'll stay right here. I'm a witch, and you can't tell me what to do."
"I'm a witch. I don't like formalities, and I don't like waiting."

The woman took a step back.

"A witch? Are you -- Eldest Lady?"
"I'm a witch. That's business enough."

The woman took a step back.

"A witch? Are you -- Eldest Lady?"
"No business at all."
"Then you should go."
"Very well."
"Wait, wait," said a voice.
[Continue.]
"Minister?"
[Continue.]

"Captain Ismene, let me speak to this newcomer."

The man turned to <FirstName>. "Our scouts saw you wandering the forest. They said you used witchcraft and fought the Congress of Moths. That crow," he said, pointing to Pharaoh on his perch, "helped you...as did some kind of monster."
"You have good scouts."
"Of course. This is a royal escort. Only the best and most loyal Dudovians travel with His Majesty."
[Continue.]
"It's a good thing your little spies did nothing to cross me."
The minister turned red. "Apologies if our vigilance offends. It is necessary in woods as dangerous as these."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> said nothing.
Pharaoh cawed and swooped down to the witch's shoulder. If the young witch wouldn't own the report, he would.
[Continue.]
"That answers my question," he said, taking a step back and eyeing the bird with wonder.
[Continue.]
"It's true, then. A witch walks in the royal camp," he said in a rather portentous way. "But I must ask -- Do you mean any harm to the king, to the kingdom of Dudow, or to any person here?"
"Of course not. I had no idea this camp existed until five minutes ago."

"This monster that was said to walk with you. Where is it?"

<FirstName> had stowed Knott away and had no intention of revealing him.
"That part of your report wasn't true."
"I see. Captain Ismene, the ambassador and I would like to speak with this witch. Give <him/her> leave to come and go as <he/she> pleases."
[Continue.]
"Yes, Your Excellency."
[Continue.]

He turned to <FirstName>.

"On behalf of His Highness, King Setus II, you are welcome here -- very welcome. It's a marvelous coincidence you're here, in fact. I'd say more, but what I have to say requires privacy. Please follow me to the king's tent."
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch met the Minister of Peace, encamped with the rest of a royal escort in the middle of the woods. He said that the witch's coming was a marvelous coincidence and that he wanted to talk in private.

subNodes.conversationText: "He's my servant and comes when called. I don't think you'd like to meet him."
"I see. Captain Ismene, the ambassador and I would like to speak with this witch. Give <him/her> leave to come and go as <he/she> pleases."
"Beating your scouts to a bloody pulp."
The man went pale.
"Only a joke," <FirstName> said.
The minister looked relieved. "Where is he, then?"
"The part in your report about the monster wasn't true," <FirstName> lied.
"I see. Captain Ismene, the ambassador and I would like to speak with this witch. Give <him/her> leave to come and go as <he/she> pleases."
"That monster is my servant and only comes when called. I don't think you'd like to meet him."
"I see. Captain Ismene, the ambassador and I would like to speak with this witch. Give <him/her> leave to come and go as <he/she> pleases."
"Not at the moment."
"And may that moment never come to pass!" cried the man. "Well, you're dangerous, but all witches are, aren't they?"
[Continue.]
"No -- but I may cause harm without meaning it."
"So may we all. Very well then."
[Continue.]

"This monster that was said to walk with you. Where is it?"

<FirstName> had stowed Knott away and had no intention of revealing him.
"I'll stay right here. I'm a witch, and you can't tell me what to do."
The outrider stood watch impassively.
[Continue.]
[End.]
